justification: “The cue-abstraction model (CAM, Pachur & Olsson, 2012) … are representative cue-based strategies,” indicating CAM is the instrument the authors use to capture cue-based strategy use.
The same sentence notes that the “weighted additive (WADD, Payne et al., 1993) model” is another representative cue-based strategy, showing WADD is employed to measure this construct.

The article states that “the weighted additive model … and take-the-best heuristic (Gigerenzer & Goldstein, 1996) are popular models for describing the behavior in pairwise comparison tasks,” and the authors implement a probabilistic ‘gTTB’ variant as the measure.

measured_by: Generalized Context Model (GCM; paired & joint versions)
justification: “To represent the exemplar-based strategies we used two versions of the generalized context model (GCM),” explicitly linking GCM to measurement of exemplar-based decision strategies.
The paper notes, “The SSL model (Rieskamp & Otto, 2006) has previously been used to describe strategy selection,” showing SSL functions as the measurement tool for strategy-selection learning.

The authors introduce “our contextual version of the reinforcement learning based strategy selection model … accounts for how people learn to associate different decision strategies to different environments,” indicating CSSL operationalizes this construct.
